When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it came (for example, if it moves above a mountain range or a river, or moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment than it was in before.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor compared to what it needed before.
The original population hasn't changed at all, it still needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself occurs beyond the influence of cultural and political forces, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, we could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
The massive ownership of cars also leads to a greater incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the resulting injuries.

Germany was a common enemy during World War II, which led to cooperation between the USSR and the United States. At the end of the war, the deep differences in their different systems, methods and cultures ended the cooperation between these two countries.
Two years after the end of the war, the former allies became enemies and the Cold War began.
It would last for the next 40 years and would see real battles, through the use of proxy armies, on fields of battle in Africa, Asia, Afghanistan, Cuba, and many other places.

Using ships to transport cargo is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across the oceans.
Traditionally, the work of navies has been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and goods, while interfering with your enemy's ability to move their people and goods.

One of the most remarkable recent examples of this situation was the North Atlantic Campaign during World War II. The Americans were trying to get soldiers and equipment across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain.
At the same time, the German Navy, using mainly U-Boats, was trying to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have conquered Britain as it did the rest of Europe.
It seems that goats were domesticated for the first time about 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains of Iran.
Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep them close by for easy access to milk, hair, meat and hides.

Domestic goats were usually kept in herds that roamed the hills or other grazing areas, often tended by shepherds who were usually children or adolescents, similar to the more common term of shepherds. These pastoral methods are still in use today.
Wagonways were built in England as early as the 16th century.

Although the wagon ways were simply made up of parallel planks of wood, they allowed the horses that pulled them to reach greater speeds and to pull heavier loads than on the slightly more accident-prone roads of the day.
Crossbars were introduced early to keep the tracks in place. However, we soon realized that the tracks would be more effective if they were equipped with a metal strip on top.
This has become a common practice, but iron has caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.
The first means of locomotion was walking: humans began walking upright two million years ago with the arrival of Homo Erectus ("upright man").
Their predecessors, the australopiths, did not walk upright as usual.
Bipedal specializations are found in the fossils of Australopithecus dating from 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have walked on two legs as early as seven million years ago.

After its adoption by Congress on July 4, a handwritten manuscript signed by Congress President John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few blocks away, to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, today known as "Dunlap Broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in Independence Hall on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy arrived in London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap copies that we know of are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived.

A binary number can only have one of two values: 0 or 1. These numbers are called binary digits, or bits, in computer jargon.

Multiple sclerosis is a disease that affects the central nervous system, composed of the brain, spinal cord and optic nerve.

Periodic rhythms, which are not simply responses to periodic external stimuli, have been documented for most living things, including bacteria, fungi, plants, and animals.
Biological clocks are self-sustaining oscillators that will continue a cycle of functioning for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.
The Hershey and Chase experiment was one of the main indications that DNA was a genetic material.
Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to insert their own DNA into a bacterium.
They conducted two experiments to mark either the DNA of the phage with radioactive phosphorus, or the protein of the phage with radioactive sulfur.

In this dynamic transportation system, everyone is somehow connected to a transportation system based on private cars and supports it.
Science now shows that this economy based on carbon has displaced the biosphere from its state of stability that has supported human evolution for two million years.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because the behavior of drivers cannot be predicted with 100% certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to act in a reasonably coherent range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be represented mathematically in an approximate manner.
To better represent traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) the flow rate, (2) density and (3) speed.
These relationships help with planning, design and operation of roadway facilities.
Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape their enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently.
Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their body.
It gives them a greater number of small places to hide from predators.
Today, the only insects that cannot fold their wings are dragonflies and mayflies.

Some thought he was right, but many believed the opposite: that the solar system was moving around the Earth, including the Sun (and even the other stars).

The Amazon River is the second-longest and largest river on Earth. It carries eight times the volume of water of the second-largest river.
Amazon is also the largest river in the world, sometimes reaching 10 km wide.
No less than 20% of the water that flows from the rivers of the planet into the oceans comes from the Amazon.
The main branch of the Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 mi) long. It collects water from thousands of small rivers.

Content theories focus on what makes people feel good or what attracts them.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that have been internalized as they mature into adulthood.
These theories examine what motivates some people to do what they do and what in their environment pushes them to do or not do certain things.
Two popular content theories are Maslow's hierarchy of needs and Herzberg's two-factor theory.
In general, two behaviors can emerge when a manager becomes the boss of former colleagues. At one end of the spectrum is to try and remain "the good friend" (or the good friend).
This type of manager has a hard time making unpopular decisions, taking disciplinary actions, conducting evaluations, delegating responsibilities, and holding others accountable.
At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels that he/she must change everything that the group has created so far and do things his/her way.
After all, the manager is ultimately responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to disputes between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Members of a virtual team often function as a point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet according to different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of a virtual team.
The "invisible team" is the management team to which each member reports. It sets the standards for each of them.

Artificial intelligence research aims to automate tasks that require intelligent approaches.

Field trips are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take their students to places where a bus trip isn't possible.

The solution is provided by technology in the form of virtual field trips. Students can view ancient artifacts from a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful work of art while sitting with their class.
Participating in an excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future generations.

For example, students from Bennet High School in North Carolina design a website each year about their visit to the state capital. Each year, the site is updated, but the previous versions are kept online to serve as an album.

Blogs can also help students to improve their writing skills. Even though students often try blogging with poor grammar and spelling, the fact that they have an audience usually improves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the blog author begins to try and improve his writing to avoid criticism.
In addition, blogging "requires students to better know the world around them." The need to generate interest from the public encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

"When used effectively, blogs can help students to strengthen their analytical and critical thinking skills: by reacting actively to online content, they can confront their opinions with those of others and expose their own views on well-defined topics (Oravec, 2002)."

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BCE, and was used by the Phoenicians, Romans, and Mérinides as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had rebuilt it and baptized it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after an earthquake.
The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all of Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tagines, pottery, leather goods, hookahs and all sorts of trinkets, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town located in the extreme east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava from the volcano Nyiragongo which buried most of the city's streets, particularly the downtown area.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma should be researched to understand the state of the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The town is also the starting point for the ascent of the Nyiragongo volcano as well as for treks among the cheapest gorilla treks in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motorcycle taxi) to get around in Goma. The normal (local) fare is about 500 Congolese francs for a short ride.
Combined with its relative inaccessibility, "Timbuktu" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.

In 1990, it was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in danger due to the threat of desert sands.
It was one of the main stops on Henry Louis Gates's PBS series, "Wonders of the African World."
The city contrasts sharply with the rest of the country, as it has an Arabic style rather than an African one.
The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa and borders the Mozambique to the east, Zimbabwe to the north and the Crocodile River to the south.
The total area of the park is 19,500 km2, which is divided into 14 ecozones, each with its own unique fauna.
It is one of the most well-known theme parks in South Africa and is considered to be the jewel in the crown of South African National Parks (SANParks).
As with all South African National Parks, there are daily entrance and conservation fees for the park.
It may be advantageous to purchase a Wild Card that gives access to some South African parks, as well as all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and is the main attraction for many tourists.

To admire the most beautiful panoramas of Hong Kong, leave the island and head to the waterfront of Kowloon, which is across the way.
The vast majority of Hong Kong's urban development is concentrated on the northern shore's reclaimed land.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove forest in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the hinterland of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans have been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called Sundarbans National Park.
Forests are not composed solely of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the Gangetic plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which about a third is covered by water/marshes.
Sundarbans is a natural reserve since 1966, you can find about 400 Bengal Royal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

The Oyapock Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to link the towns of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers rise to a height of 83 meters; it is 378 meters long and has two lanes 3.50 meters wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it wasn't opened to traffic until March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guaraní were the largest indigenous group inhabiting what is now the eastern part of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes that populated the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived primarily through fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, formerly known as "the giant province of the Indies" was born from the encounter between Spanish conquerors and indigenous populations.
The Spanish inaugurated the period of colonization, which lasted three centuries.
Since the founding of Asunción in 1537, Paraguay has succeeded in preserving a great deal of its indigenous character and identity.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands pound (FKP) whose value is equivalent to a pound sterling (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the islands located in Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a commonly accepted currency throughout the islands, while at Stanley, credit cards and US dollars are also often accepted.
On nearby islands, credit cards are unlikely to be accepted, even if it is possible that British and American currencies will be. Speak to the owners in advance to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falklands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.

German pastries are pretty good, and in Bavaria they are very rich and varied, similar to those of their southern neighbor, Austria.

Indonesia having 17,000 islands, Indonesian cuisine is a generic term that covers a wide variety of regional cuisines present throughout the country.

The stirrups are foot supports for the rider, which hang on either side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth, narrow sole.
Then, some saddles, especially English ones, have safety bars that allow a stirrup to fall off the saddle if it is pulled backward by a rider who falls.

Skiing is a major travel activity that has many aficionados, sometimes called "ski bums", who organize their entire vacations around skiing in specific places.
The idea of skiing is very old: cave paintings showing skiers date back to 5,000 years B.C.!
Alpine skiing as a sport dates back at least to the 17th century; the first ski club was founded in 1861 in Australia by Norwegians.
Ski touring: this activity is also known as Nordic skiing, cross-country skiing or ski touring.
It's similar to alpine ski touring, as well as alpinism, without generally incorporating these activities, which are practiced on rugged terrain and require the use of stiffer skis and boots.
Think of a ski trail as a hiking trail.
In good conditions, you can cover slightly longer distances than on foot – but you will rarely reach the speeds of cross country skiing without a heavy pack on damaged trails.

Europe is a relatively small continent, but with many independent countries. In normal circumstances, travelling through several countries means having to make several visa requests and passport checks.
However, the Schengen area functions somewhat like a single country in this regard.
As long as you stay in this zone, you can generally cross borders without having to go through passport control again.
Similarly, if you have a Schengen visa, you do not need to apply separately for a visa for each of the Schengen countries, which saves time, money and administrative hassles.

Violent weather is the generic term for any dangerous meteorological phenomenon which can cause damage, serious social upheaval, or loss of human life.
Extremely unfavorable weather conditions can occur anywhere in the world, and they can be of several types, depending on the geographical, topographical, and atmospheric characteristics.
Violent winds, hail, excessive rainfall, and fires are forms and effects of violent weather, just as thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, and typhoons.
Extreme weather phenomena, regional and seasonal, include cold fronts, snowstorms with strong winds, and sandstorms or dust storms.
It is strongly advised to travelers to research the risks of bad weather that may affect their destination region, knowing that this may have an impact on the itineraries they are considering.

Japanese work culture is more hierarchical and formal than that to which Westerners may be accustomed.
The costumes are classic work attire, and employees are addressed by their family name or job title.
Workplace harmony is crucial, because it puts the emphasis on collective effort rather than individual accomplishments.
Workers are often required to get the approval of their superiors for any decision they make and are expected to obey their superiors without question.
